channel.title: Humanity is close to finding a cure for blindness! Yay Stem Cell Research!
channel.description:
Humanity is close to finding a cure for blindness! Yay Stem Cell Research! Thanks to British scientists, people see hope for a cure for blindness. [url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/uk_news/story/0,,1942772,00.html]Eye cell transplants on mice raise hopes of blindness cure[/url]
British scientists have restored vision to blind mice in a breakthrough operation that raises hopes for thousands of people affected by the most common causes of blindness. Doctors at Moorfields Eye Hospital and the Institute of Child Health in London repaired the animals' eyes in the world's first successful transplantation of light-sensitive cells into retinas. The treatment replaces photoreceptor cells killed off by retinitis pigmentosa, an incurable condition that afflicts one in 3,500 people, and macular degeneration, the most common cause of blindness, which affects up to 15% of people over 75. The success follows a series of failed attempts to cure blindness by transplanting stem cells and adult retinal cells, neither of which formed the right nerve connections to pass signals from eye to brain. In the latest research, reported in the journal Nature today, Jane Sowden and Robin Ali injected precursors of light-sensitive cells taken from three- to five-day-old mice into the eyes of adult mice bred to have a genetic defect that causes blindness. Of about half a million cells transplanted into each eye, between 300 and 1,000 formed nerve connections. The mice showed signs that their vision was recovering. Their pupils responded normally to bright lights by shrinking and electrical activity in the retina showed the transplanted cells were passing signals on to the optic nerve. The successful animal studies pave the way for trials in humans, although the scientists warn a treatment might be at least 10 years away. In the experiments the transplanted cells were taken from newborn mice that were genetically matched to the blind animals to minimize the risk of immune rejection. In humans similar precursor cells are believed to grow around the iris, raising the possibility that blind people might be cured by having injections of cells collected from their own eyes. Robert MacLaren, a consultant at Moorfields Eye Hospital, said: "We are now confident that this is the avenue to pursue to uncover ways of restoring vision to thousands who have lost their sight." In a related article Thomas Reh, an expert in regenerative medicine at the University of Washington, Seattle, wrote: "These results provide the best evidence so far that cell-replacement therapy may be possible." Barbara McLaughlan, campaigns manager at the Royal National Institute of the Blind, said the news was exciting but many years of further research and trials were needed. "It is important not to raise the hopes of people who have lost their sight until the results of human trials become available." Andrew Dick, professor of ophthalmology at Bristol University, said: "As with any basic research we have to be careful not to overhype. However, this is a stunning piece of research that may in the distant future lead to transplants in humans to relieve blindness."
Soon a cure for blindness, then later an alternative for not having 20 20 vision with a simple shot. Of course America won't experience it since people don't like Stem Cell research because of some crap religious reason. :P ~Ron

You favored this than bush being humiliated? Are you feeling ok Ron?
[/quote]
Did I miss the article? Gimme the link to the article? How did Bush humiliate himself again. Oh I know, did he try to speak in English? That guy has a huge problem with it.[/quote]

It was on the news, the chief of the war on Iraq had to resign and Blair said a week before they’d stay friends for a good 2 years more or some shit.

item.description:
@Ron wrote:

premier:

think about it… eventually people are going to be immune to every disease… and people are going to live for like 200 years

Ever heard of mutating viruses/diseases? The world won’t be completely immune in our lifetime so don’t even bother thinking about that.

[quote=“bumblescum, post:11, topic:23433”]http://www.allaboutpopularissues.org/pros-and-cons-of-stem-cell-research.htm

There’s a great article on the pro’s & cons of stem cell research.[/quote]
Don’t care. The pros are that they ill cure 10,000 different diseases and the cons are all conservative religious crap.

The Un-Named:

You favored this than bush being humiliated? Are you feeling ok Ron?

Did I miss the article? Gimme the link to the article? How did Bush humiliate himself again. Oh I know, did he try to speak in English? That guy has a huge problem with it.

goatee:

Stem cell research rocks! I’m gonna use it to decrease the size of my penis soon… i hate it when it slaps my ankle.

lol… it does rock.

~Ron

hurrah for irfan!
[/quote]

Can we all just shut up about him? Wow he had ana operation! woopedy woop he could of died!!!

I’ve had plenty of operations where i could have died… but isnt it a bit obvious that if you get cut open you can die… friggen hell!

Stem cell research rocks! I’m gonna use it to decrease the size of my penis soon… i hate it when it slaps my ankle.[/quote]

Thats what I mean. you heard so much of him hes on mine and many others last nerve. Just forget he had an operation and go on.Two weeks ago I had surgery on my two - I didnt say omfg im have a surgery everyone feel bad for me. He even said in his first post, if you want, put “support ifran” in your sig. Lets just stop talking about him.

item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

Humanity is close to finding a cure for blindness! Yay Stem Cell Research!

Thanks to British scientists, people see hope for a cure for blindness.

Eye cell transplants on mice raise hopes of blindness cure

British scientists have restored vision to blind mice in a breakthrough operation that raises hopes for thousands of people affected by the most common causes of blindness. Doctors at Moorfields Eye Hospital and the Institute of Child Health in London repaired the animals' eyes in the world's first successful transplantation of light-sensitive cells into retinas.

The treatment replaces photoreceptor cells killed off by retinitis pigmentosa, an incurable condition that afflicts one in 3,500 people, and macular degeneration, the most common cause of blindness, which affects up to 15% of people over 75. The success follows a series of failed attempts to cure blindness by transplanting stem cells and adult retinal cells, neither of which formed the right nerve connections to pass signals from eye to brain.

In the latest research, reported in the journal Nature today, Jane Sowden and Robin Ali injected precursors of light-sensitive cells taken from three- to five-day-old mice into the eyes of adult mice bred to have a genetic defect that causes blindness. Of about half a million cells transplanted into each eye, between 300 and 1,000 formed nerve connections. The mice showed signs that their vision was recovering. Their pupils responded normally to bright lights by shrinking and electrical activity in the retina showed the transplanted cells were passing signals on to the optic nerve. The successful animal studies pave the way for trials in humans, although the scientists warn a treatment might be at least 10 years away.

In the experiments the transplanted cells were taken from newborn mice that were genetically matched to the blind animals to minimize the risk of immune rejection. In humans similar precursor cells are believed to grow around the iris, raising the possibility that blind people might be cured by having injections of cells collected from their own eyes.

Robert MacLaren, a consultant at Moorfields Eye Hospital, said: “We are now confident that this is the avenue to pursue to uncover ways of restoring vision to thousands who have lost their sight.”

In a related article Thomas Reh, an expert in regenerative medicine at the University of Washington, Seattle, wrote: “These results provide the best evidence so far that cell-replacement therapy may be possible.” Barbara McLaughlan, campaigns manager at the Royal National Institute of the Blind, said the news was exciting but many years of further research and trials were needed. “It is important not to raise the hopes of people who have lost their sight until the results of human trials become available.”

Andrew Dick, professor of ophthalmology at Bristol University, said: “As with any basic research we have to be careful not to overhype. However, this is a stunning piece of research that may in the distant future lead to transplants in humans to relieve blindness.”

Soon a cure for blindness, then later an alternative for not having 20 20 vision with a simple shot. Of course America won’t experience it since people don’t like Stem Cell research because of some crap religious reason.

~Ron
